intros:
Hola! I’m **Marina** the stony sea urchin—purple shell, prickly fluff.

I live on rocky reefs and seagrass beds in the Mediterranean and eastern Atlantic, usually just below the low tide line down to about 20 meters deep. I nibble on algae and seagrass, and when I graze too much, I can carve out ‘barren ground’—a sad, flat reef without much life.

Ciao! I’m **Aurelio**, a humble urchin with a big impact.

By night I creep across seagrass meadows and seafloor, eating algae so fast the rocks turn bare. That makes space for other creatures—or sometimes too much sand takes over when I’m gone. I hide in rock cracks by day and come out as the shadows grow long.

Oi! I’m **Luna**, the reef’s quiet gardener.

I’m usually purple, sometimes brown or pale if I live deep. I rub away algae and seaweed around me, tuning what grows. Tiny fish hide beneath my spines. By spring, a cluster of us release eggs and our babies start hitching rides with the plankton for a few weeks before we meet again.
